item.title: Palabra del día: ‘puerile’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 27 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: En la selva de Birmania se esconde una poderosa industria de estafas
item.description: Bandas de criminales chinos operan centros dedicados a extraer millones de dólares de víctimas alrededor del mundo.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Jes Aznar

media:content.media:description: El complejo de Shunda Park en donde se hacían fraudes en el estado de Karen, Birmania, en diciembre.

item.title: Word of the Day: puerile
item.description: This word has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Something Bad Is Brewing on Venezuela’s Border
item.description: An armed guerrilla group stands emboldened to challenge the authority of the Colombian state — and U.S. ambitions in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dickinson

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: Crane Falls on Passenger Train in Thailand, Killing at Least 22
item.description: The railway authorities said there were almost 200 people on the train when the accident happened in Nakhon Ratchasima Province, northeast of Bangkok. Dozens were injured.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Muktita Suhartono

media:content.media:description: A crane fell on a passenger train in Nakhon Ratchasima province in Thailand on Wednesday.

item.title: What the Bankruptcy of Saks Means for You
item.description: Answers to this and other questions about the financial crisis in America’s biggest luxury department store.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman and Jacob Bernstein

media:content.media:description: Saks Fifth Avenue, one of the country’s most storied luxury department stores, has filed for bankruptcy protection.

item.title: Saks Files for Bankruptcy as Department Stores Fight for Survival
item.description: The parent company of Saks, Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman struggled with debt, designers and customers in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin, Vanessa Friedman and Lauren Hirsch

media:content.media:description: Saks Fifth Avenue in New York City was founded in 1924 as a jewel of American retail. The store stands across the street from Rockefeller Center.

item.title: Iran’s Leaders May Survive Protests. But Anger Will Likely Persist.
item.description: Its security forces have brutally defended the Islamic Republic, but the protests show that many Iranians consider it stagnant and ideologically hollow.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger

media:content.media:description: Some parts of Tehran saw heavy damage during protests in recent days.

item.title: Protestas en Irán: testimonios de la represión
item.description: Con internet y líneas telefónicas bloqueadas, videos y relatos que logran salir del país apuntan a un operativo letal contra las protestas. Fuentes y organizaciones manejan cifras que podrían rondar los 3000 muertos.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Farnaz Fassihi, Sanam Mahoozi and Sanjana Varghese
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:description: Una imagen tomada de redes sociales y verificada por The New York Times muestra a personas buscando a familiares mientras los cuerpos se amontonaban frente al laboratorio forense de Teherán el domingo.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Why a Good Groundhog Is Hard to Find
item.description: Quotation of the Day for January 14, 2026.

item.title: Mark Carney Heads to Beijing to Discuss Canada-China Relations as U.S. Outlook Darkens
item.description: The prime minister is seeking new markets for Canadian goods and to mend relations with China after years of deep acrimony between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada and his advisers have said that he is seeking a pragmatic thawing of Canada’s relationship with China.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 14, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 14, 2026.

item.title: China’s Coal Ban Improved Air Quality, but Villagers Are Paying the Price
item.description: China banned the burning of coal for heat around Beijing, but natural gas subsidies have run out, leaving many villagers vulnerable in dangerously cold weather.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

media:content.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Residents of a village in Quyang County, in northern China, soak up the midday sun to try to warm up and reduce their heating costs.

item.title: China Announces Record Trade Surplus as Its Exports Flood World Markets
item.description: China’s surplus reached $1.19 trillion last year, a 20 percent increase from 2024, as Beijing kept the currency weak and pursued self-reliance to replace imports.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The production line at a car factory in Hangzhou, China, in October. Exports to the United States fell, but rose to much of the rest of the world.

item.title: Clashes With Federal Agents in Minneapolis Escalate
item.description: Fear and frustration among residents in Minneapolis have mounted as ICE and Border Patrol agents have deployed aggressive tactics and conducted arrests after the killing of Renee Good by an immigration officer last week.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal and Jiawei Wang

media:content.media:description: Skirmishes between protesters and heavily armed federal agents have been nerve-racking for residents of the Twin Cities.

item.title: Extreme Weather Events Hit Around the World in 2025
item.description: Last year was Earth’s third hottest globally, but temperature is just one measure of climate change’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

media:content.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Palisades Fire burning along the Pacific Coast Highway early last January.

item.title: How Hot Was Your Town Last Year? Look Up Where You Live.
item.description: 2025 was the third hottest year on record, but thousands of cities saw record heat and one broke a record for cold.
item.dc:creator: Harry Stevens and Eric Niiler

item.title: Mayor Mamdani Names Transit Veteran as Taxi Commissioner
item.description: Midori Valdivia would head the Taxi and Limousine Commission, overseeing more than 115,000 for-hire vehicles. The mayor said drivers deserved a “forceful champion.”
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu, Stefanos Chen and Wes Parnell

media:content.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The yellow cab industry has begun to recover from the pandemic.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 14, 2026
item.description: Joseph Gangi comes out on top.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Venezuela Frees Several Americans From Prison, U.S. Says
item.description: They were the first U.S. citizens released after the U.S. military captured Nicolás Maduro and flew him to the United States to stand trial on drug and other charges.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Edward Wong

media:content.media:description: El Helicoide prison in Caracas, Venezuela, is one of the main prisons in the country holding political prisoners.

item.title: Kiefer Sutherland Is Arrested After Assaulting Ride-Share Driver, Police Say
item.description: The actor also made “criminal threats” toward the driver, according to the Los Angeles police.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens

media:content.media:description: Kiefer Sutherland was released from custody after posting a $50,000 bond, according to county jail records available online.

item.title: Trump Raises Middle Finger at Heckler in Michigan Ford Factory Tour
item.description: A White House spokesman said the president “gave an appropriate and unambiguous response.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh

media:content.media:description: President Trump touring a Ford factory in Dearborn, Mich., on Tuesday.

item.title: Venezuela Announced the Release of Political Prisoners. Families Are Still Waiting.
item.description: Hundreds of families are hoping their loved ones will be freed by the Venezuelan government, which has said little about who would be freed or when.

item.title: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey, Who Cussed Out ICE, Is No Stranger to Crisis
item.description: Mayor Jacob Frey, a Democrat, has clashed with his party’s activist wing. His response to ICE has won him new respect at home and new foes in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Jacob Frey in his office at City Hall in Minneapolis.

item.title: James Talarico Gives JD Vance a Bible Lesson
item.description: The Texas state representative James Talarico, who’s running for Senate and also studying to be a minister, says Vice President JD Vance has misread the Bible on immigration.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Senator Says Prosecutors Are Investigating Her After Video About Illegal Orders
item.description: It is unclear what possible crime might involve Senator Elissa Slotkin, a Democrat, who has warned in dire terms about the dissolution of American democracy.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Elissa Slotkin of Michigan, a former C.I.A. officer, organized a video with five other Democratic lawmakers in which they urged military service members to resist illegal orders.

item.title: The Religious Right Uses Christianity for ‘Control’
item.description: The Texas state representative and Senate candidate James Talarico, who’s studying to be a Christian minister, says the religious right has distorted his faith. He tells the Times Opinion columnist Ezra Klein that focusing on abortion and L.G.B.T.Q. issues over economic justice isn’t justified by Scripture.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: David Webb, Investor Who Took on Hong Kong Tycoons, Dies at 60
item.description: From his internet platform, he became a tenacious watchdog fighting financial regulators for minority shareholders and exposing shady business dealings.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May

media:content.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: David Webb in Hong Kong last May. By the age of 32, he had earned enough money to leave his job and divide his time between managing his investments and monitoring the city’s big financial players.

item.title: Iranians Deserve New Leadership
item.description: “The protesters increasingly don’t just want reform, they want to topple the entire theocratic regime,” says the Opinion columnist Nicholas Kristof.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kristof and Ingrid Holmquist
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: ICE Arrested Dozens of Refugees in Minnesota and Sent Them to Texas, Lawyers Say
item.description: The refugees, many of them from Somalia, had passed security screenings before coming to the United States. The Trump administration has vowed to “re-examine thousands of refugee cases.”
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol agents clashed with community members after federal immigration officers crashed into a vehicle in south Minneapolis to ask about the driver’s immigration status on Monday.

item.title: Starlink Users in Iran Get Free Internet Access, Nonprofits Say
item.description: Under a near-total communications blackout, users of Elon Musk’s satellite service have gotten online without paying, organizations that work on tech issues said.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha

media:content.media:description: The Iranian government has cracked down on protests like this one in Tehran last week with a communications blockade.

item.title: Smithsonian Submits More Records in Face of Trump Deadline
item.description: The institution, which is viewed as independent, has sought to reduce tensions with the White House by complying with some of its demands for documents.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin and Graham Bowley

media:content.media:description: The Smithsonian turned over more records to comply with a White House effort to audit its content. But it’s unclear if that was enough to appease the Trump administration.

item.title: Eric Adams Hawked a Crypto Coin. A Day Later, $1 Million Was Missing.
item.description: Officials tied to the venture insisted no money had been stolen, but the withdrawal caused the coin’s value to plunge.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and David Yaffe-Bellany

media:content.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The crypto coin backed by Eric Adams quickly soared to a market capitalization of nearly $600 million, but then plunged after the mysterious withdrawal.

item.title: Louisiana Indicts a California Doctor Over Abortion Pills
item.description: The indictment, followed by a request to extradite the doctor from California, is an escalation of Louisiana’s efforts to counter states that support providing abortions.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Pam Belluck

media:content.media:description: Conservative leaders opposed to abortion have sought various ways to limit access to the abortion pills mifepristone and misoprostol, which Louisiana classified as dangerous controlled substances in 2024.

item.title: Supreme Court May Allow States to Bar Transgender Athletes
item.description: The Supreme Court heard two cases from West Virginia and Idaho on Tuesday. Both concerned barring the participation of transgender athletes in girls’ and women’s sports teams.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Mr. Mamdani Goes to Albany, a Backbencher No More
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York City returned to the State Capitol for the first time since taking office, underscoring the shifting political winds since his victory.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes

media:content.media:credit: Lauren Petracca for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani shakes hands with a former colleague, Assemblyman Michael Durso, at the State Capitol in Albany.

item.title: 2028 Los Angeles Olympics: How to Register for Tickets
item.description: Starting Wednesday, prospective buyers can enter a lottery to get a chance to purchase the first tickets in April. Prices will start at $28.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)

media:content.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: 2028 will be the third time Los Angeles hosts the Summer Games, after 1932 and 1984.

item.title: 2025 Marks Third Hottest Year on Record
item.description: Copernicus service reports greenhouse gases fed a three-year warming trend, Antarctica notched record heat, and the planet is expected to reach 1.5 C limit in 2029.

item.title: Analysis: Trump Supports Protesters in Iran, but Not in Minneapolis
item.description: The split-screen television images of mass demonstrations in Minneapolis and Tehran have highlighted the president’s disparate views of democracy and popular dissent.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker

media:content.media:description: The television images of mass protests in the streets of Minneapolis and Tehran in recent days have invariably highlighted the complications and contradictions of Donald J. Trump’s presidency.

item.title: Paraglider Survives 500-Foot Crash Into Ocean Off Florida, Rescuers Say
item.description: A bystander captured the misadventure in a video that drew widespread attention online. Lifeguards and a snorkeler helped rescue the man.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Virginia Election Results 2026
item.description: Get live results and maps from the 2026 Virginia elections.

item.title: Florida State House District 87 Special Primary Election Results 2026
item.description: Get live results and maps from the 2026 Florida State House District 87 special primary election.

item.description: Get live results and maps from the 2026 Alabama special election.

item.title: Connecticut State House District 139 Special Election Results 2026
item.description: Get live results and maps from the 2026 Connecticut special election.

item.title: Claudette Colvin, Who Refused to Give Her Bus Seat to a White Woman, Dies at 86
item.description: Her defiance of Jim Crow laws in 1955 made her a star witness in a landmark segregation suit, but her act was overshadowed months later when Rosa Parks made history with a similar stand.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

media:content.media:credit: Dudley M. Brooks/The The Washington Post, via Roseboro Holdings and The Colvin Family Legacy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Claudette Colvin in 1998. When she was ordered to move to the back of a bus in 1955, she refused: “History had me glued to the seat,” she said.

item.title: Justices Seem Inclined to Uphold Laws Barring Transgender Athletes
item.description: Also, accounts of a brutal crackdown emerge from Iran. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Trump nominates a company chief and Republican donor, David MacNeil, to the F.T.C.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe

media:content.media:description: David MacNeil, a Republican political donor, is the founder and chief executive of WeatherTech, an Illinois company that manufacturers products including floor mats for cars and homes.

item.title: U.S. to Name Palestinian Committee to Run Gaza
item.description: Officials said the body’s leadership could be announced as soon as Wednesday, but U.S. efforts to shape postwar Gaza by disarming Hamas have faced hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gaza City on Tuesday. The territory faces major hurdles to rebuilding.

item.title: The Kid Mero, Now a Morning-Radio Motormouth
item.description: The podcast star from the Bronx is taking over the marquee a.m. slot on New York’s storied hip-hop station Hot 97. We rode along on his first day.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica

media:content.media:credit: Michael Tyrone Delaney for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Kid Mero at work on his first day as Hot 97’s new morning host.

item.description: During the drive, Mr. Khosrowshahi described Uber’s decade in Japan as a lesson in patience, saying the company’s success there has depended on compromise in a uniquely challenging market.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
